summary: (At six, Tony stares up at stars, bruises bursting along his cheeks like bombs, and he thinks - he hopes - he prays - "I want to...
question: (At six, Tony stares up at stars, bruises bursting along his cheeks like bombs, and he thinks - he hopes - he prays - "I want to be up there one day." And there will be a time, much later, when he is staring at the stars and the stars are staring back, a planet at his back and dead son on his shoulders, that he remembers this and thinks "the one time someone heard my prayers, and they grant me this".) (Can you tell I'm still shaking with a sugar rush? Cause I am.)
answer:
Ouch. This hurt on so many levels, my dude. Your sugar rush is more of an angst rush.

I can see Tony thinking this when he’s slightly rocking himself with Peter’s dust still clinging to him and “Please, I don’t wanna go” playing on repeat in his head.

summary: Could you possibly make a headcanon of Peter walking up to everyone in the stone and saying he needs cuddles because he's scared...
question: Could you possibly make a headcanon of Peter walking up to everyone in the stone and saying he needs cuddles because he's scared and eventually one of the others give in and cuddle with him?
answer:
This would be an awesome fic! Maybe Peter wakes up after a nightmare and starts walking around while crying. Then, maybe he finds a bunch of people and is like, “I’m scared and in desperate need of a hug.” No one in the group seems to know him, then from behind the group, Bucky steps up to Peter and does that one arm hug Tony usually does with Peter and says, “Don’t worry Spider-Man, Tony will stop at nothing to get you back home safe and sound. He cares so much about you and I bet he’s doing everything to find you. You’re the only reason why he’s still trying.” When Peter hears this, he begins to truly believe that everything will be okay. His dad is Iron Man after all.

Thanks for sharing this amazing idea!😊 I’m sorry if it’s not that good, it’s my first time doing this.

summary: Mini rant here kay: "Tony would if you were a beautiful woman" uh huh pal. Like Steve "I kissed my almost-girlfriends niece"...
question: Mini rant here kay: "Tony would if you were a beautiful woman" uh huh pal. Like Steve "I kissed my almost-girlfriends niece" isn't worse. Like that isn't a thing that happened? In IW, Tony helps a woman back onto her feet. Fuck you, pal, for trying to insult the pure, unbridled "I will help the world, big or small" that is Tony Stark, force of nature and nurture.
answer:
(Also I’m rly proud of that “Tony Stark, force of nature and nurture” thing I said in my last ask and now I want fic! Just revolving around that line. I’m gon do it maybe) 

Lmao, I love you. 

I can’t fucking stand when people post that type of stuff. Just like with that illustrator that said Tony wouldn’t buy Peter’s wrapping paper for a fundraiser. Tony who literally went to Yinsen’s village and killed all of the terrorists, thanked Harley by remaking the garage into a lab, literally just meets Bruce and invites him to come to the tower, equipped Peter’s suit with everything so that he’d be safe, AND in the comics he goes and holds baby orphans. 

Like… who the hell…. Tony is an extremely caring person and would do anything to help others. If people want to shame Tony for things he did in the past the fiinneeee, but that means that they have to shame all of the others for their pasts as well. And they can fight me on that. 

Also 100x yes. That would be a great fic and I want to read it.

title: I Need Help (Forgetting You: Part 1)
body:
A/N: hiiiii. I hope you all had the best holidays, and I wish you all a happy new year! this is the first part of my very first Peter Parker series: Forgetting You. I want to thank @twilightparker for being so sweet and encouraging and so so so supportive when it came to this series, thank you so much for your help and kindness <3. This series is inspired by the movie Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind. I hope you guys enjoy, please give me some feedback and hit that reblog button if you did!

Warnings: kinda dark but not too dark, angst, tears? really depends on you lol, peter is sad

Word Count: 2.8 K

It was rainy that day. In fact, it was rainy all the time. It wasn’t heavy rain, but if you listened closely enough, you could definitely hear the sound of raindrops tap-tapping against the windows of the apartment. Where there is rain, there are clouds, and sure enough, the dome above the skyscrapers of New York was grey and cool. You often hear of people whose moods eventually match the weather outside, but you never hear the opposite. One’s happiness does not mean the sun will come out and make everyone feel warm. Yet somehow, with Peter’s broken heart came the storms outside his apartment in Queens. It was as though the sky had heard him sob in the night and had started to cry with him, accompanying him throughout his lonely journey to recovery.

Recovery was far from being achieved. Peter had been holed up in his home for months, refusing to speak to anyone, refusing to face the city and it’s problems. Peter couldn’t do anything - not even breathe before the urge to throw up or start sobbing uncontrollably emerged; he was a mess. He felt empty, yet his tears never ceased. He’d find himself lying on the floor, wiping at his eyes over and over again, wondering how he was still able to cry, how he still had enough energy to do so.

The worst moments were when he’d get up from whatever surface he’d been lying on and go to the fridge, or the bathroom, or the fire escape, or the hall. The fact was, anytime he went anywhere in his little apartment, anytime his bloodshot eyes would fall onto a particular object, be it a magnet, or a toothbrush or the old ashtray outside, and he’d be thrown back into old memories, excruciating memories he had been trying to leave behind for months.

With one glance, he’d be sent to a time where pain was ignored and replaced by temporary bliss. He had tried, he had worked for so long to make that happiness last, but it hadn’t stuck. When a vase you adore more than anything in the world is broken, you do whatever it takes to repair it, even if it means gluing every little piece of porcelain back together, even if it takes you months to do so. But sometimes, when you try and fix what has been broken, you end up breaking something far more important: yourself.

Peter had learned that the hard way. And perhaps it was too late, maybe he was unmendable. That would explain why hadn’t stopped hurting ever since she had disappeared from his life.

It was about half past four in the afternoon. The rain was still pouring onto the streets of New York and because of that, the usual sound of traffic didn’t fill Peter’s ears. In fact, the apartment was dead silent.

Peter was lying on his stomach on his unmade bed, his head facing the wall in front of him. His arms lay on either sides of his body, motionless as though he couldn’t feel them. He barely blinked as he kept on staring at the light grey wall. His eyes were tired and the huge circles beneath them were proof that he hadn’t slept in a while.

Then all of a sudden, the sound of the home telephone ringing snapped Peter out of his daze and he pulled his eyes away from the wall, instead turning around slowly to look at the object from across the hall. The cordless phone was resting on a small coffee table right next to the front door. As Peter looked at it, he felt a pang of anger fill his chest and he stood up, calmly.

Placing one foot in front of the other, he slowly made his way out his bedroom and into the main room. He ignored the area, including his Spiderman mask that had been left forgotten in the corner of the room with a bunch of other mundane objects, his cold gaze still focused on the phone who hadn’t stopped ringing yet. Finally, he reached the front door and with a darkness in his eyes, Peter grabbed the phone and immediately hurtled it at the floor, smashing it to pieces. The ringing stopped instantly, but the sound of the impact echoed in Peter’s mind, the previous silence long forgotten.

Barely avoiding the pile of phone fragments, the young man walked into his kitchen and stopped in front of his fridge. Sure enough, a memory started seeping back in Peter’s head and he winced as the hurt settled in.

“We have beer, tomatoes, milk that’s gone bad and what looks like cheese but I can’t be sure.”

Peter shook his head aggressively, trying to block out the memory of her voice, desperately. But in vain. As her words sneakily crept into his mind, Peter violently punched the fridge, yelping as pain erupted in his balled up hand and he stumbled backwards, his back eventually hitting the tiled wall. He slid down and landed on the dusty floor. He hadn’t cleaned up the apartment in weeks. Breathing heavily, Peter buried his face and his hands and started sobbing, the action so strong he shook with every tear.

He couldn’t take it anymore, he couldn’t handle the pain. It was too much. He felt like his insides were being torn apart over and over again. Every time he did anything, he felt sick to his stomach with grief and sadness. He would do anything, anything at all to get rid of it all, to get rid of the feeling he’d get whenever he remembered her face, or her perfume, or the way she talked. He was desperate.

Then suddenly, he lifted his head, fat tears still rolling down his flushed cheeks.

The reason why he couldn’t get over what had happened to him was because every little thing was still engraved in his mind, and evidence was displayed everywhere around his apartment. Everywhere he looked, she was there, along with her remains. So in order for him to move on, maybe all he needed to do was forget. Forget the girl, forget the pain, and live. After so many months of sadness and misery, maybe he’d be able to achieve the recovery he’d been trying so hard to reach.

But he would have to forget everything, every single detail of the past year and a half that concerned the subject of his nightmares. How does one forget so much?

Maybe, just maybe, with the help of a certain Tony Stark.

After changing into some clean clothes, Peter took a cab and about an hour later, he arrived at the Avengers Facility. Peter hoarsely thanked the cab driver before turning around. His eyes rested on the large A that decorated the imposing building, the A he had once proudly considered himself a part of. He hadn’t come here in months.

Peter started walking towards the building, his feet occasionally walking into small puddles, but he didn’t care about that nor did he care about the rain pouring down on him. He had to find Tony.

Inside the facility, warm air enveloped Peter’s humid body. He had missed this place, he realised. He’d missed the glass doors and tall concrete walls, and that feeling he got whenever he walked through those main doors. That feeling of responsibility.

It had been a while, but the only difference between now and then was that now he wasn’t here because of his responsibility. It wasn’t like before, and that fact made him feel even worse.

The main hall was empty, no one was there. Peter didn’t dwell on it and walked in the direction of the elevators, moving fast when he suddenly heard his name being called. He halted and hesitantly, he turned around, his eyes resting on Natasha.

“Peter?” she asked, eyes wide in shock. She hadn’t seen him in so long, no one had.

At the sight of his old friend and teammate, Peter’s eyes welled up and for a minute Natasha could have sworn he was going to come over there and hug her, but he didn’t. Instead he shook his head, wiping away his fresh tears as he spoke.

“I have to see Mr. Stark,” he said, his voice wobbly and breaking mid-sentence.

Without saying anything else, Peter turned his back on Natasha and pressed the elevator button. The doors opened and he entered swiftly, trying to get away from the blonde woman he missed dearly. If he couldn’t face her, how could he face Mr. Stark? No, he couldn’t try and back out now. He needed Tony.

Peter nodded with resolve and pushed his fears and troubling thoughts from his mind. Or at least he tried to.

As the elevator went further up, Peter’s heart started beating faster and faster, his breath shortening. His hands were moist and not because of the rain that had greeted him outside. He was nervous, in fact he was terrified. He hadn’t talked to Tony in so long, too long. The truth was, he had been ashamed of himself. Ashamed of his behavior during the past few months, ashamed of his emotional turmoil. He had always wanted Tony to think he was strong and fearless, but the truth was he was weak. Peter didn’t want to let his hero down, yet throughout every passing minute of his self-inflicted house arrest, he had done just that.

The doors opening interrupted Peter’s racing thoughts and he took a shaky breath before hesitantly leaving the elevator.

The main room was just like he remembered it. There were big black leather couches in the center of the room that had been bought by Tony a few months after the Avengers had brought back the victims of Thanos’ attack on the universe, and Peter remembers because he’d helped to pick them out. Glass bookshelves and tables rested in every corner of the room, a large aluminum chandelier hung from the shiny white ceiling, and nothing really had changed. He could almost see himself standing there, holding a large book about Nanotech, excitedly reading certain passages out loud to a very amused Tony who had of course already read those exact words before. He never said so though, choosing rather to let Peter passionately ramble on and on.

Tony had always made sure that the main room stayed intact and clean. The real mess that you’d expect from a genius inventor slash engineer like him was hidden away in the lab, a couple of feet down the hallway on Peter’s left. Knowing Tony, he was most probably hidden there as well, buried beneath tons of files, scraps of metal, and coffee.

Peter walked towards the lab, his heart racing and his fingers quaking a little. He sniffed as his feet walked over a familiar metal plate on the floor and the plate started to turn along with the wall in front of him, swiveling so that he found himself on the other side. And sure enough, before him stood Tony, a wire cutter in his hands and a coffee stain on his t-shirt.

“Peter?” the man asked, his expression clouded by confusion as his dark brown eyes swept over his visitor.

Peter blinked, trying to keep welling tears at bay, and then looked away shamefully.

“Hey, Mr. Stark,” he answered, his voice quiet and hoarse.

The air between the two of them was heavy and tense, both trying to figure out what to say. Tony simply stared at Peter, his lips slightly parted as racing thoughts filled his mind.

Peter was here, standing in front of him. It had been so long. And he looked absolutely terrible, what had she done to him?

“I-uh…I need your help,” Peter croaked, still refusing to meet Tony’s gaze.

“Of course, what do you need?” He asked immediately. He hated seeing Peter like this. He was almost unrecognizable. He had truly never looked this tired and hopeless before.

Peter suddenly lunged forward, grabbing Tony’s shoulders to keep himself up. He was exhausted, so tired of everything.

Tony, though shocked, wrapped his arms around him and winced at the sound of strangled sobs leaving Peter’s chest. The broken man shook as he gripped Tony’s shirt, his knuckles turning white. He had always been like a father to him, someone he looked up to but more importantly, depended on. For some reason, Tony had always stuck by him, no matter what, even if it meant putting himself at risk.

He had missed him terribly.

“I need your help,” Peter sobbed in the crook of Tony’s neck.

“I know, I know. You’re okay, kid,” replied Tony, shutting his eyes as he rubbed Peter’s back with his firm hands.

The pair continued to hug for a few minutes, Peter’s cries eventually calming down. Peter and Tony had only ever hugged once before: it was the day the Avengers had saved him and billions of others around the globe, the day he came back from the void he had been sent to by Thanos and the Infinity stones. Tony, relieved and grateful, had wrapped his arms around the then-teenager and held on so tightly that he had almost broken Peter’s ribs.

Finally, Peter pulled away and hesitantly wiped at his eyes, inhaling deeply.

Tony walked over to the little seating area by a spiral staircase in the room. He gestured to one of the leather arm chairs, and Peter took the hint and sat down, his gaze locked onto the floor beneath his humid feet, sniffling a couple of times.

“Do you want something to drink? Like, a soda, or water-,”

“-I’m fine,” Peter muttered, cutting Tony off.

Tony nodded as he bit his lip, unsure as to what to say to the young man sitting across from him. He waited patiently for Peter to speak, rubbing circles in the palm of his right hand. He was nervous for some reason.

“I’m sorry I haven’t called you back,” Peter finally said, still looking down. “I just- didn’t really know what to say.”

“It’s okay. You’ve had a lot going on,” replied Tony, his voice gentle.

“Yeah. I-uh, I haven’t been sleeping much. I’m not doing well.”

Tony nodded slowly, his expression saddening.

“Mr. Stark, I need you to do something for me.”

This made Tony sit up straighter and clear his throat, curious as to what Peter was going to ask of him. Of course, he’d do anything for him, but besides being a shoulder for him to cry on and a person to talk to every now and then, he didn’t really see what else he could do.

“I remember coming here a couple of years ago. You had a few projects going on.”

“Yes, a bunch of prototypes.”

“Right.” Peter took in a deep shaky breath. “Do you still have the Memory Card?”

Tony froze. “The Memory Card, why would you need the Memory Card?” he asked, startled.

Peter looked down and his hands started to quake softly.

“Mr. Stark. I don’t want to remember her anymore.”

“Peter-,”

“-every time I do anything, I see her. I see what she did and I hear what she said- and it hurts so much.”

“I understand that, Peter, but, it’s a prototype. And we’re talking about taking months worth of memories from your brain and stocking them in a computer file. Not only is it extremely dangerous, but this is something that requires extensive planning and a lot of thought-,”

“-I have been thinking. For months!” Peter raised his voice, anger slowly rising in his abdomen. “You have no idea. I’ve been torturing myself, every day, trying to move on from her, from those memories. I can’t do it anymore. You have no idea how bad it hurts.”

Tony shook his head slowly, his eyes still closed. This kid was insane. It was a dangerous ordeal, one he couldn’t believe they were even discussing. If something went wrong, if there was even the tiniest glitch, Peter could very well lose everything: his memories, his personality, his life. It was dramatic to even think about that, but Tony would in fact be tampering with Peter’s brain. With an untested prototype. Anything could happen.

“I know it’s dangerous. And it probably won’t work. Yeah, maybe all my memories get deleted. Honestly, at this point, I just don’t care anymore. Please, please, Mr. Stark. I don’t want to remember her anymore. I just want to move on, for good.”

At this point, a fat tear had escaped the confines of Peter’s left eye and slowly rolled down his cheek, landing on his hoodie. He was shaking a little, and his eyes were wide with desperation.

Tony knew it was a huge gamble, but for Peter, he would roll the dice.

A/N: aaaah, what did you guys think?? are you curious about the memory card? ooh what do you guys think happened with Peter and his ex??

also tagging @petalparker <3

It was rainy that day. In fact, it was rainy all the time. It wasn’t heavy rain, but if you listened closely enough, you could definitely hear the sound of raindrops tap-tapping against the windows of the apartment. Where there is rain, there are clouds, and sure enough, the dome above the skyscrapers of New York was grey and cool. You often hear of people whose moods eventually match the weather outside, but you never hear the opposite. One’s happiness does not mean the sun will come out and make everyone feel warm. Yet somehow, with Peter’s broken heart came the storms outside his apartment in Queens. It was as though the sky had heard him sob in the night and had started to cry with him, accompanying him throughout his lonely journey to recovery.

Recovery was far from being achieved. Peter had been holed up in his home for months, refusing to speak to anyone, refusing to face the city and it’s problems. Peter couldn’t do anything - not even breathe before the urge to throw up or start sobbing uncontrollably emerged; he was a mess. He felt empty, yet his tears never ceased. He’d find himself lying on the floor, wiping at his eyes over and over again, wondering how he was still able to cry, how he still had enough energy to do so.

[[MORE]]

The worst moments were when he’d get up from whatever surface he’d been lying on and go to the fridge, or the bathroom, or the fire escape, or the hall. The fact was, anytime he went anywhere in his little apartment, anytime his bloodshot eyes would fall onto a particular object, be it a magnet, or a toothbrush or the old ashtray outside, and he’d be thrown back into old memories, excruciating memories he had been trying to leave behind for months.

With one glance, he’d be sent to a time where pain was ignored and replaced by temporary bliss. He had tried, he had worked for so long to make that happiness last, but it hadn’t stuck. When a vase you adore more than anything in the world is broken, you do whatever it takes to repair it, even if it means gluing every little piece of porcelain back together, even if it takes you months to do so. But sometimes, when you try and fix what has been broken, you end up breaking something far more important: yourself.

Peter had learned that the hard way. And perhaps it was too late, maybe he was unmendable. That would explain why hadn’t stopped hurting ever since she had disappeared from his life.

It was about half past four in the afternoon. The rain was still pouring onto the streets of New York and because of that, the usual sound of traffic didn’t fill Peter’s ears. In fact, the apartment was dead silent.

Peter was lying on his stomach on his unmade bed, his head facing the wall in front of him. His arms lay on either sides of his body, motionless as though he couldn’t feel them. He barely blinked as he kept on staring at the light grey wall. His eyes were tired and the huge circles beneath them were proof that he hadn’t slept in a while.

Then all of a sudden, the sound of the home telephone ringing snapped Peter out of his daze and he pulled his eyes away from the wall, instead turning around slowly to look at the object from across the hall. The cordless phone was resting on a small coffee table right next to the front door. As Peter looked at it, he felt a pang of anger fill his chest and he stood up, calmly.

Placing one foot in front of the other, he slowly made his way out his bedroom and into the main room. He ignored the area, including his Spiderman mask that had been left forgotten in the corner of the room with a bunch of other mundane objects, his cold gaze still focused on the phone who hadn’t stopped ringing yet. Finally, he reached the front door and with a darkness in his eyes, Peter grabbed the phone and immediately hurtled it at the floor, smashing it to pieces. The ringing stopped instantly, but the sound of the impact echoed in Peter’s mind, the previous silence long forgotten.

Barely avoiding the pile of phone fragments, the young man walked into his kitchen and stopped in front of his fridge. Sure enough, a memory started seeping back in Peter’s head and he winced as the hurt settled in.

“We have beer, tomatoes, milk that’s gone bad and what looks like cheese but I can’t be sure.”

Peter shook his head aggressively, trying to block out the memory of her voice, desperately. But in vain. As her words sneakily crept into his mind, Peter violently punched the fridge, yelping as pain erupted in his balled up hand and he stumbled backwards, his back eventually hitting the tiled wall. He slid down and landed on the dusty floor. He hadn’t cleaned up the apartment in weeks. Breathing heavily, Peter buried his face and his hands and started sobbing, the action so strong he shook with every tear.

He couldn’t take it anymore, he couldn’t handle the pain. It was too much. He felt like his insides were being torn apart over and over again. Every time he did anything, he felt sick to his stomach with grief and sadness. He would do anything, anything at all to get rid of it all, to get rid of the feeling he’d get whenever he remembered her face, or her perfume, or the way she talked. He was desperate.

Then suddenly, he lifted his head, fat tears still rolling down his flushed cheeks.

The reason why he couldn’t get over what had happened to him was because every little thing was still engraved in his mind, and evidence was displayed everywhere around his apartment. Everywhere he looked, she was there, along with her remains. So in order for him to move on, maybe all he needed to do was forget. Forget the girl, forget the pain, and live. After so many months of sadness and misery, maybe he’d be able to achieve the recovery he’d been trying so hard to reach.

But he would have to forget everything, every single detail of the past year and a half that concerned the subject of his nightmares. How does one forget so much?

Maybe, just maybe, with the help of a certain Tony Stark.

After changing into some clean clothes, Peter took a cab and about an hour later, he arrived at the Avengers Facility. Peter hoarsely thanked the cab driver before turning around. His eyes rested on the large A that decorated the imposing building, the A he had once proudly considered himself a part of. He hadn’t come here in months.

Peter started walking towards the building, his feet occasionally walking into small puddles, but he didn’t care about that nor did he care about the rain pouring down on him. He had to find Tony.

Inside the facility, warm air enveloped Peter’s humid body. He had missed this place, he realised. He’d missed the glass doors and tall concrete walls, and that feeling he got whenever he walked through those main doors. That feeling of responsibility.

It had been a while, but the only difference between now and then was that now he wasn’t here because of his responsibility. It wasn’t like before, and that fact made him feel even worse.

The main hall was empty, no one was there. Peter didn’t dwell on it and walked in the direction of the elevators, moving fast when he suddenly heard his name being called. He halted and hesitantly, he turned around, his eyes resting on Natasha.

“Peter?” she asked, eyes wide in shock. She hadn’t seen him in so long, no one had.

At the sight of his old friend and teammate, Peter’s eyes welled up and for a minute Natasha could have sworn he was going to come over there and hug her, but he didn’t. Instead he shook his head, wiping away his fresh tears as he spoke.

“I have to see Mr. Stark,” he said, his voice wobbly and breaking mid-sentence.

Without saying anything else, Peter turned his back on Natasha and pressed the elevator button. The doors opened and he entered swiftly, trying to get away from the blonde woman he missed dearly. If he couldn’t face her, how could he face Mr. Stark? No, he couldn’t try and back out now. He needed Tony.

Peter nodded with resolve and pushed his fears and troubling thoughts from his mind. Or at least he tried to.

As the elevator went further up, Peter’s heart started beating faster and faster, his breath shortening. His hands were moist and not because of the rain that had greeted him outside. He was nervous, in fact he was terrified. He hadn’t talked to Tony in so long, too long. The truth was, he had been ashamed of himself. Ashamed of his behavior during the past few months, ashamed of his emotional turmoil. He had always wanted Tony to think he was strong and fearless, but the truth was he was weak. Peter didn’t want to let his hero down, yet throughout every passing minute of his self-inflicted house arrest, he had done just that.

The doors opening interrupted Peter’s racing thoughts and he took a shaky breath before hesitantly leaving the elevator.

The main room was just like he remembered it. There were big black leather couches in the center of the room that had been bought by Tony a few months after the Avengers had brought back the victims of Thanos’ attack on the universe, and Peter remembers because he’d helped to pick them out. Glass bookshelves and tables rested in every corner of the room, a large aluminum chandelier hung from the shiny white ceiling, and nothing really had changed. He could almost see himself standing there, holding a large book about Nanotech, excitedly reading certain passages out loud to a very amused Tony who had of course already read those exact words before. He never said so though, choosing rather to let Peter passionately ramble on and on.

Tony had always made sure that the main room stayed intact and clean. The real mess that you’d expect from a genius inventor slash engineer like him was hidden away in the lab, a couple of feet down the hallway on Peter’s left. Knowing Tony, he was most probably hidden there as well, buried beneath tons of files, scraps of metal, and coffee.

Peter walked towards the lab, his heart racing and his fingers quaking a little. He sniffed as his feet walked over a familiar metal plate on the floor and the plate started to turn along with the wall in front of him, swiveling so that he found himself on the other side. And sure enough, before him stood Tony, a wire cutter in his hands and a coffee stain on his t-shirt.

“Peter?” the man asked, his expression clouded by confusion as his dark brown eyes swept over his visitor.

Peter blinked, trying to keep welling tears at bay, and then looked away shamefully.

“Hey, Mr. Stark,” he answered, his voice quiet and hoarse.

The air between the two of them was heavy and tense, both trying to figure out what to say. Tony simply stared at Peter, his lips slightly parted as racing thoughts filled his mind.

Peter was here, standing in front of him. It had been so long. And he looked absolutely terrible, what had she done to him?

“I-uh…I need your help,” Peter croaked, still refusing to meet Tony’s gaze.

“Of course, what do you need?” He asked immediately. He hated seeing Peter like this. He was almost unrecognizable. He had truly never looked this tired and hopeless before.

Peter suddenly lunged forward, grabbing Tony’s shoulders to keep himself up. He was exhausted, so tired of everything.

Tony, though shocked, wrapped his arms around him and winced at the sound of strangled sobs leaving Peter’s chest. The broken man shook as he gripped Tony’s shirt, his knuckles turning white. He had always been like a father to him, someone he looked up to but more importantly, depended on. For some reason, Tony had always stuck by him, no matter what, even if it meant putting himself at risk.

He had missed him terribly.

“I need your help,” Peter sobbed in the crook of Tony’s neck.

“I know, I know. You’re okay, kid,” replied Tony, shutting his eyes as he rubbed Peter’s back with his firm hands.

The pair continued to hug for a few minutes, Peter’s cries eventually calming down. Peter and Tony had only ever hugged once before: it was the day the Avengers had saved him and billions of others around the globe, the day he came back from the void he had been sent to by Thanos and the Infinity stones. Tony, relieved and grateful, had wrapped his arms around the then-teenager and held on so tightly that he had almost broken Peter’s ribs.

Finally, Peter pulled away and hesitantly wiped at his eyes, inhaling deeply.

Tony walked over to the little seating area by a spiral staircase in the room. He gestured to one of the leather arm chairs, and Peter took the hint and sat down, his gaze locked onto the floor beneath his humid feet, sniffling a couple of times.

“Do you want something to drink? Like, a soda, or water-,”

“-I’m fine,” Peter muttered, cutting Tony off.

Tony nodded as he bit his lip, unsure as to what to say to the young man sitting across from him. He waited patiently for Peter to speak, rubbing circles in the palm of his right hand. He was nervous for some reason.

“I’m sorry I haven’t called you back,” Peter finally said, still looking down. “I just- didn’t really know what to say.”

“It’s okay. You’ve had a lot going on,” replied Tony, his voice gentle.

“Yeah. I-uh, I haven’t been sleeping much. I’m not doing well.”

Tony nodded slowly, his expression saddening.

“Mr. Stark, I need you to do something for me.”

This made Tony sit up straighter and clear his throat, curious as to what Peter was going to ask of him. Of course, he’d do anything for him, but besides being a shoulder for him to cry on and a person to talk to every now and then, he didn’t really see what else he could do.

“I remember coming here a couple of years ago. You had a few projects going on.”

“Yes, a bunch of prototypes.”

“Right.” Peter took in a deep shaky breath. “Do you still have the Memory Card?”

Tony froze. “The Memory Card, why would you need the Memory Card?” he asked, startled.

Peter looked down and his hands started to quake softly.

“Mr. Stark. I don’t want to remember her anymore.”

“Peter-,”

“-every time I do anything, I see her. I see what she did and I hear what she said- and it hurts so much.”

“I understand that, Peter, but, it’s a prototype. And we’re talking about taking months worth of memories from your brain and stocking them in a computer file. Not only is it extremely dangerous, but this is something that requires extensive planning and a lot of thought-,”

“-I have been thinking. For months!” Peter raised his voice, anger slowly rising in his abdomen. “You have no idea. I’ve been torturing myself, every day, trying to move on from her, from those memories. I can’t do it anymore. You have no idea how bad it hurts.”

Tony shook his head slowly, his eyes still closed. This kid was insane. It was a dangerous ordeal, one he couldn’t believe they were even discussing. If something went wrong, if there was even the tiniest glitch, Peter could very well lose everything: his memories, his personality, his life. It was dramatic to even think about that, but Tony would in fact be tampering with Peter’s brain. With an untested prototype. Anything could happen.

“I know it’s dangerous. And it probably won’t work. Yeah, maybe all my memories get deleted. Honestly, at this point, I just don’t care anymore. Please, please, Mr. Stark. I don’t want to remember her anymore. I just want to move on, for good.”

At this point, a fat tear had escaped the confines of Peter’s left eye and slowly rolled down his cheek, landing on his hoodie. He was shaking a little, and his eyes were wide with desperation.

Tony knew it was a huge gamble, but for Peter, he would roll the dice.

Peter and Tony had only ever hugged once before: it was the day the Avengers had saved him and billions of others around the globe, the day he came back from the void he had been sent to by Thanos and the Infinity stones. Tony, relieved and grateful, had wrapped his arms around the then-teenager and held on so tightly that he had almost broken Peter’s ribs.

Finally, Peter pulled away and hesitantly wiped at his eyes, inhaling deeply.

Tony walked over to the little seating area by a spiral staircase in the room. He gestured to one of the leather arm chairs, and Peter took the hint and sat down, his gaze locked onto the floor beneath his humid feet, sniffling a couple of times.

“Do you want something to drink? Like, a soda, or water-,”

“-I’m fine,” Peter muttered, cutting Tony off.

Tony nodded as he bit his lip, unsure as to what to say to the young man sitting across from him. He waited patiently for Peter to speak, rubbing circles in the palm of his right hand. He was nervous for some reason.

“I’m sorry I haven’t called you back,” Peter finally said, still looking down. “I just- didn’t really know what to say.”

“It’s okay. You’ve had a lot going on,” replied Tony, his voice gentle.

“Yeah. I-uh, I haven’t been sleeping much. I’m not doing well.”

Tony nodded slowly, his expression saddening.

“Mr. Stark, I need you to do something for me.”

This made Tony sit up straighter and clear his throat, curious as to what Peter was going to ask of him. Of course, he’d do anything for him, but besides being a shoulder for him to cry on and a person to talk to every now and then, he didn’t really see what else he could do.

“I remember coming here a couple of years ago. You had a few projects going on.”

“Yes, a bunch of prototypes.”

“Right.” Peter took in a deep shaky breath. “Do you still have the Memory Card?”

Tony froze. “The Memory Card, why would you need the Memory Card?” he asked, startled.

Peter looked down and his hands started to quake softly.

“Mr. Stark. I don’t want to remember her anymore.”

“Peter-,”

“-every time I do anything, I see her. I see what she did and I hear what she said- and it hurts so much.”

“I understand that, Peter, but, it’s a prototype. And we’re talking about taking months worth of memories from your brain and stocking them in a computer file. Not only is it extremely dangerous, but this is something that requires extensive planning and a lot of thought-,”

“-I have been thinking. For months!” Peter raised his voice, anger slowly rising in his abdomen. “You have no idea. I’ve been torturing myself, every day, trying to move on from her, from those memories. I can’t do it anymore. You have no idea how bad it hurts.”

Tony shook his head slowly, his eyes still closed. This kid was insane. It was a dangerous ordeal, one he couldn’t believe they were even discussing. If something went wrong, if there was even the tiniest glitch, Peter could very well lose everything: his memories, his personality, his life. It was dramatic to even think about that, but Tony would in fact be tampering with Peter’s brain. With an untested prototype. Anything could happen.

“I know it’s dangerous. And it probably won’t work. Yeah, maybe all my memories get deleted. Honestly, at this point, I just don’t care anymore. Please, please, Mr. Stark. I don’t want to remember her anymore. I just want to move on, for good.”

At this point, a fat tear had escaped the confines of Peter’s left eye and slowly rolled down his cheek, landing on his hoodie. He was shaking a little, and his eyes were wide with desperation.

Tony knew it was a huge gamble, but for Peter, he would roll the dice.

It was rainy that day. In fact, it was rainy all the time. It wasn’t heavy rain, but if you listened closely enough, you could definitely hear the sound of raindrops tap-tapping against the windows of the apartment. Where there is rain, there are clouds, and sure enough, the dome above the skyscrapers of New York was grey and cool. You often hear of people whose moods eventually match the weather outside, but you never hear the opposite. One’s happiness does not mean the sun will come out and make everyone feel warm. Yet somehow, with Peter’s broken heart came the storms outside his apartment in Queens. It was as though the sky had heard him sob in the night and had started to cry with him, accompanying him throughout his lonely journey to recovery.

Recovery was far from being achieved. Peter had been holed up in his home for months, refusing to speak to anyone, refusing to face the city and it’s problems. Peter couldn’t do anything - not even breathe before the urge to throw up or start sobbing uncontrollably emerged; he was a mess. He felt empty, yet his tears never ceased. He’d find himself lying on the floor, wiping at his eyes over and over again, wondering how he was still able to cry, how he still had enough energy to do so.
